urn:contentItem:5VPJ-TCV1-JB20-G032-00000-00Donald Trump Says It's Time For U.S. To Recognize Israel's Sovereignty; Boeing Faces First Order Cancellation For 737 MAX Jets Since Crash; Trump On Green New Deal; Comey Op-Ed On Mueller Rpt; One-On-One With Trump2019-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:48ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTMatt SchlappNEWSFinancial032203cb.231Donald Trump Says It's Time For U.S. To Recognize Israel's Sovereignty; Boeing Faces First Order Cancellation For 737 MAX Jets Since Crash; Trump On Green New Deal; Comey Op-Ed On Mueller Rpt; One-On-One With TrumpMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Jon Hilsenrath, Gerri Willis, Cheryl Casone, Stuart Varney, Jason Chaffetz

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, March 22nd. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. My exclusive interview with President Trump coming up. The Commander-in-Chief speaking out on his surprise Golan Heights announcement yesterday. Now Syria slamming the President this morning and vowing to recovery Golan Heights.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I have been thinking about doing it for a long time. It's been a very hard decision for every President. No President has done it. Every President has said, do that. I'm the one that gets it done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Part two of my exclusive interview with the President coming up right here. Meanwhile this, the deadly 737 Max crash hitting Boeing's bottom line. The jetmaker is facing its first Max order cancellation.

Apple on top. The technology giant set to unveil its streaming service on Monday. And the stock is higher ahead of the announcement. Take a look. Plus, the 2019 IPO boom is heating up. Uber and Pinterest reportedly making their choices on where they will list their stock. What that means for timeline to go public this morning.

And we're looking at weakness at the open. We are off of the lows of the morning but futures indicating a decline of 134 points. This is taking a cue from Europe because we have the Purchasing Manager's Indexes out in the Eurozone. They were weaker than expected. So the U.S. market is following Europe lower. Futures indicating a decline 13 on the S&P and 26 points lower on the NASDAQ.

After a rally yesterday meanwhile, technology stocks led the way yesterday. Take a look at the Dow at the close up 216 points yesterday. The S&P was up 30 and the NASDAQ was up 110 points, 1-1/2 percent on the hills of strength intact. In Europe this morning, those PMI's, Purchasing Managers' Index is really weighing on markets. FT-100 down 1-1/4 percent. The CAC quarante is down better than one percent and the DAX Index in Germany weaker by three-quarters of a percent, 82 points lower.

In Asia overnight, fractional movers across the board but they were higher All those stories coming up this Friday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the American Conservative Union Chairman, Matt Schlapp, and the Wall Street Journal's Global Economics Editor, Jon Hilsenrath. Great to see everybody this morning.

MATT SCHLAPP, CHAIRMAN, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: Great to be here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Great to see you, Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: They do.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: There is this -- the economy going on in the markets right now about growth, the stock market is near these new highs but the bond market is signaling that the whole world economy is slowing down. That's s why those PMI numbers that you mentioned, the lead up were really interesting. The bond market seems to be right about what's going on with the growth but the stock market doesn't care. They're buying in part because the Fed is keeping policies --

BARTIROMO: Because where the Fed is but in Europe I feel like there's not a lot of wiggle room if things continue to worsen.

HILSENRATH: There's -- no, rates are already negative.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HILSENRATH: So that's why those PMI numbers you mentioned are really important because there's very little that they can do if they fall into recession.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we'll keep watching that. Meanwhile, we begin with part two of my exclusive interview with President Trump right now. The Commander-in-Chief laying out the reasons why he suddenly declared it is time for the United States to recognize Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights. We began though with the impending release of the Mueller report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: And now we're going to get the Mueller report. What are you expecting?

TRUMP: Well, it's always interesting to me because a deputy that didn't get votes appoints a man that didn't get any votes. He's going to write a report on me. I had one of the greatest elects victories in history. Would you say that's true?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Absolutely.

TRUMP: They came from the valleys, they came from the rivers, they came from the cities, they came from all over, they voted in one of the greatest elections in the history of our country and now I have a man that because we have an attorney general who -- nobody can even believe that, he didn't tell me but he recused himself. So I have a man who was a deputy, who I don't know - who I didn't know at all and he appoints a man who had just left my office. I didn't give him job at the FBI. Comey his best friend.

BARTIROMO: So we covered every --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: Wait a minute. Listen. And you know better than anybody, you've been very fair to me on that. But think of it, I have a deputy appoints a man to write a report on me, to make a determination of my presidency? People will not stand for it. Now, with all of that being said for two years we've gone through this nonsense, with -- because there's no collusion with the Russia, you know that better than anybody.

And there's no obstruction to say, oh, wait, there was no collusion, that was a hoax but he obstruct it and fighting against the hoax, OK? Think about that one for a second.

BARTIROMO: And at the same time, the same group is running the Hillary Clinton investigation and now we heard from the Lisa Page testimony which was released that the Obama Department of Justice suggested we're not going to bring charges, so get off of this. So, during the campaign I remember you said, look, it's time to get away from Hillary Clinton, let's forget about this now.

Do you still feel that way or do you think you want to see a accountability here given the fact that now we know that the DOJ under Obama did say we're not going to bring charges to the FBI.

TRUMP: That's great question. So when I won, I made my opening speech everyone chanting lock her up, lock her up, lock her up. I said, no, no, no, let's forget it. Let's get on to the future but they have treated me so viciously, they have treated me so badly and we did nothing wrong. You look at the other -- and all of these people you hear about, that had nothing to do with Russia, Russia collusion, nothing.

It's all a big hoax, it's a witch-hunt and it's a hoax. So you asked me a question, it's very interesting question. The way they've treated me and we have found many crimes on the other side. These are stone-cold crimes what they've done between the deletion of 33,000 e-mails and many, many other things, Comey is lying, all of the Brenman lying, the lies to Congress and these are just absolute lies to Congress.

Clapper lied to Congress. Nobody does anything. If somebody -- they all say Flynn, I don't know anything about what he said but the FBI said he didn't lie. Mueller said he did lie. So what's that all about? And then they destroy a man who is a general and a respected man for many years. They've treated -- we have -- we have been treated very, very unfairly. All because Jeff Sessions didn't have a clue, OK? And he recused himself.

BARTIROMO: Will William Barr follow this? Will --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: I think -- look, I have a lot of respect for him, I've never known him, he is a very, very smart respected man. Hopefully he will do what's fair.

BARTIROMO: And now --

DOBBS: And all I can ask you is what's fair.

BARTIROMO: Mueller is going to drop the report, the southern districts is on you, there's -- these other investigations by the Democrats.

TRUMP: Well, you know, they say there are lots of things but I don't know about these things, OK? Just so you understand. Everyone says this one, that one. I don't even know about this. I call, I said to my lawyers, are we being looked at here? They don't even know what people are talking about. There's so much fake news out there, it's a disgrace. If you look over the past two years, how many breaking news stories was there about me that turned out to be nonexistent? So many of them.

BARTIROMO: How you going to get anything done with all of this?

TRUMP: This should never happen to another President. What happened to me, they came up with an excuse for losing an election, this should never happen to another President because most Presidents wouldn't be able to take it. I know the politicians, I know the President, I know -- I know what we're dealing with. Most people wouldn't be able to take it. Let me tell you something, Maria.

What happened to me should never happen to another President of the United States, because I depend on this right here, mine, not other people.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TRUMP: And what they've done is a fraud. It's a fake. It's a witch-hunt. It should never happen to another President.

BARTIROMO: Is there anything you see that you would like to work with the Democrats on in these next two years?

BARTIROMO: Yes. We could work on a lot. We could work on a lot. And I think the easiest thing frankly of all I could have started with number but one I want to get the tax cuts which we got. The easiest thing is infrastructure, they want it, I want it, I spoke to Nancy Pelosi about it the other day. We agree on it. We even like the type -- I think we like the type of infrastructure we're talking about.

Maybe in a certain way more Democrats from our standpoint than the Republican concept. Private, public. I like frankly owning our own roads, owning our bridges. I don't like selling them to other countries.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- they don't want you to have any victor.

TRUMP: I think it's very feasible because I think they want to do it. I mean, Nancy Pelosi told me very strongly they want to do infrastructure and we have other things we can do too. I we should do something on immigration, immigration is a total disaster in this country. We have laws that are so bad. People pouring in. I'll tell you what, border security, border patrol, what they've done is incredible.

The job they're doing, the job that ISIS is doing, what they're doing, without the protection and the ability to have a wall now -- and by the way, we're building a lot of wall right now, you know that. We're building the wall and it's going up fast, big, strong, looks good, not the horrible thing that they were building before I got here. We're building the wall now. We're going to have a lot of wall built pretty soon. But if you don't have that, you can't have border security.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to go up against in 2020?

TRUMP: So you have people saying a lot of weird things, you know, I hear not only the Green New Deal but so many others, so many things.

BARTIROMO: Medicare of All, tax on wealth, 70 percent tax rates.

TRUMP: You have -- you have Beto -- so you have Beto and Beto comes out and he says, let's take down the wall. If you ever took down the wall, this country would be overrun, OK? And we put up a lot of wall like in San Diego, so interesting, you have California. So, in San Diego they're begging me to do the wall. I end up doing the wall and then I see Governor of California criticizes me for the wall.

They're begging me do it. Because if you don't have it and they know this better. It's all a political deal, it's all politics. But --

BARTIROMO: You want to run against Beto?

TRUMP: You know, my attitude is -- I wouldn't mind. I mean, I'd love to have Biden, I'd love to have Bernie, I'd love to have Beto. I mean, Beto seems to be the one the press has chosen. The press seems to have chosen Beto.

BARTIROMO: Is this socialism versus capitalism?

TRUMP: And when I watched Beto, I say, we could dream about that but whatever it is, no, I think it's competence, I think if somebody -- look, when I first ran, I was never a politicians. I ran -- I ran in a certain platform. I've done far more than I said I was going to do. When you look at the tax cuts, when you look at the regulation cuts, more than any other President. When you look at all -- it's the biggest tax cut. You look at --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: You look at even a thing like right to try, what people can now use if they're terminally ill and they can use medicines that we've developed but that aren't out by signing a simple document. They used to travel to Asia, to Europe, all over the world to try and get a cure. BARTIROMO: Are they going to be able to do an enforcement enough to actually keep China to its promises to not steal I.P.?

HILSENRATH: That's one of many issues and that's why one of the things he said is important, that they want to keep some of these tariffs in place until they see some of this -- some of these agreements coming to fruition.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: He also said to you which made my ears burn, no to zero tariffs with Europe on automobiles. And he actually praised the 25 percent import tariffs on light trucks, called the Chicken Tax, which your viewers know because we've talked about it literally for two years on this program.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That was important, you're right, the zero taxes. He doesn't want to go there.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: That will do it for today. Thanks, everybody. Great panel, great program. Have a great weekend. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Friday, March 22nd. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. My exclusive interview with President Trump coming up. The Commander-in-Chief speaking out on his surprise Golan Heights announcement yesterday. Now Syria slamming the President this morning and vowing to recovery Golan Heights.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I have been thinking about doing it for a long time. It's been a very hard decision for every President. No President has done it. Every President has said, do that. I'm the one that gets it done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Part two of my exclusive interview with the President coming up right here. Meanwhile this, the deadly 737 Max crash hitting Boeing's bottom line. The jetmaker is facing its first Max order cancellation.

Apple on top. The technology giant set to unveil its streaming service on Monday. And the stock is higher ahead of the announcement. Take a look. Plus, the 2019 IPO boom is heating up. Uber and Pinterest reportedly making their choices on where they will list their stock. What that means for timeline to go public this morning.

And we're looking at weakness at the open. We are off of the lows of the morning but futures indicating a decline of 134 points. This is taking a cue from Europe because we have the Purchasing Manager's Indexes out in the Eurozone. They were weaker than expected. So the U.S. market is following Europe lower. Futures indicating a decline 13 on the S&P and 26 points lower on the NASDAQ.

After a rally yesterday meanwhile, technology stocks led the way yesterday. Take a look at the Dow at the close up 216 points yesterday. The S&P was up 30 and the NASDAQ was up 110 points, 1-1/2 percent on the hills of strength intact. In Europe this morning, those PMI's, Purchasing Managers' Index is really weighing on markets. FT-100 down 1-1/4 percent. The CAC quarante is down better than one percent and the DAX Index in Germany weaker by three-quarters of a percent, 82 points lower.

In Asia overnight, fractional movers across the board but they were higher All those stories coming up this Friday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the American Conservative Union Chairman, Matt Schlapp, and the Wall Street Journal's Global Economics Editor, Jon Hilsenrath. Great to see everybody this morning.

MATT SCHLAPP, CHAIRMAN, AMERICAN CONSERVATIVE UNION: Great to be here.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Great to see you, Maria Bartiromo.

BARTIROMO: They do.

JON HILSENRATH, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: There is this -- the economy going on in the markets right now about growth, the stock market is near these new highs but the bond market is signaling that the whole world economy is slowing down. That's s why those PMI numbers that you mentioned, the lead up were really interesting. The bond market seems to be right about what's going on with the growth but the stock market doesn't care. They're buying in part because the Fed is keeping policies --

BARTIROMO: Because where the Fed is but in Europe I feel like there's not a lot of wiggle room if things continue to worsen.

HILSENRATH: There's -- no, rates are already negative.

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

HILSENRATH: So that's why those PMI numbers you mentioned are really important because there's very little that they can do if they fall into recession.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Well, we'll keep watching that. Meanwhile, we begin with part two of my exclusive interview with President Trump right now. The Commander-in-Chief laying out the reasons why he suddenly declared it is time for the United States to recognize Israel's sovereignty over the Golan Heights. We began though with the impending release of the Mueller report.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: And now we're going to get the Mueller report. What are you expecting?

TRUMP: Well, it's always interesting to me because a deputy that didn't get votes appoints a man that didn't get any votes. He's going to write a report on me. I had one of the greatest elects victories in history. Would you say that's true?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Absolutely.

TRUMP: They came from the valleys, they came from the rivers, they came from the cities, they came from all over, they voted in one of the greatest elections in the history of our country and now I have a man that because we have an attorney general who -- nobody can even believe that, he didn't tell me but he recused himself. So I have a man who was a deputy, who I don't know - who I didn't know at all and he appoints a man who had just left my office. I didn't give him job at the FBI. Comey his best friend.

BARTIROMO: So we covered every --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: Wait a minute. Listen. And you know better than anybody, you've been very fair to me on that. But think of it, I have a deputy appoints a man to write a report on me, to make a determination of my presidency? People will not stand for it. Now, with all of that being said for two years we've gone through this nonsense, with -- because there's no collusion with the Russia, you know that better than anybody.

And there's no obstruction to say, oh, wait, there was no collusion, that was a hoax but he obstruct it and fighting against the hoax, OK? Think about that one for a second.

BARTIROMO: And at the same time, the same group is running the Hillary Clinton investigation and now we heard from the Lisa Page testimony which was released that the Obama Department of Justice suggested we're not going to bring charges, so get off of this. So, during the campaign I remember you said, look, it's time to get away from Hillary Clinton, let's forget about this now.

Do you still feel that way or do you think you want to see a accountability here given the fact that now we know that the DOJ under Obama did say we're not going to bring charges to the FBI.

TRUMP: That's great question. So when I won, I made my opening speech everyone chanting lock her up, lock her up, lock her up. I said, no, no, no, let's forget it. Let's get on to the future but they have treated me so viciously, they have treated me so badly and we did nothing wrong. You look at the other -- and all of these people you hear about, that had nothing to do with Russia, Russia collusion, nothing.

It's all a big hoax, it's a witch-hunt and it's a hoax. So you asked me a question, it's very interesting question. The way they've treated me and we have found many crimes on the other side. These are stone-cold crimes what they've done between the deletion of 33,000 e-mails and many, many other things, Comey is lying, all of the Brenman lying, the lies to Congress and these are just absolute lies to Congress.

Clapper lied to Congress. Nobody does anything. If somebody -- they all say Flynn, I don't know anything about what he said but the FBI said he didn't lie. Mueller said he did lie. So what's that all about? And then they destroy a man who is a general and a respected man for many years. They've treated -- we have -- we have been treated very, very unfairly. All because Jeff Sessions didn't have a clue, OK? And he recused himself.

BARTIROMO: Will William Barr follow this? Will --

(CROSSTALK)

DOBBS: I think -- look, I have a lot of respect for him, I've never known him, he is a very, very smart respected man. Hopefully he will do what's fair.

BARTIROMO: And now --

DOBBS: And all I can ask you is what's fair.

BARTIROMO: Mueller is going to drop the report, the southern districts is on you, there's -- these other investigations by the Democrats.

TRUMP: Well, you know, they say there are lots of things but I don't know about these things, OK? Just so you understand. Everyone says this one, that one. I don't even know about this. I call, I said to my lawyers, are we being looked at here? They don't even know what people are talking about. There's so much fake news out there, it's a disgrace. If you look over the past two years, how many breaking news stories was there about me that turned out to be nonexistent? So many of them.

BARTIROMO: How you going to get anything done with all of this?

TRUMP: This should never happen to another President. What happened to me, they came up with an excuse for losing an election, this should never happen to another President because most Presidents wouldn't be able to take it. I know the politicians, I know the President, I know -- I know what we're dealing with. Most people wouldn't be able to take it. Let me tell you something, Maria.

What happened to me should never happen to another President of the United States, because I depend on this right here, mine, not other people.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

TRUMP: And what they've done is a fraud. It's a fake. It's a witch-hunt. It should never happen to another President.

BARTIROMO: Is there anything you see that you would like to work with the Democrats on in these next two years?

BARTIROMO: Yes. We could work on a lot. We could work on a lot. And I think the easiest thing frankly of all I could have started with number but one I want to get the tax cuts which we got. The easiest thing is infrastructure, they want it, I want it, I spoke to Nancy Pelosi about it the other day. We agree on it. We even like the type -- I think we like the type of infrastructure we're talking about.

Maybe in a certain way more Democrats from our standpoint than the Republican concept. Private, public. I like frankly owning our own roads, owning our bridges. I don't like selling them to other countries.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: -- they don't want you to have any victor.

TRUMP: I think it's very feasible because I think they want to do it. I mean, Nancy Pelosi told me very strongly they want to do infrastructure and we have other things we can do too. I we should do something on immigration, immigration is a total disaster in this country. We have laws that are so bad. People pouring in. I'll tell you what, border security, border patrol, what they've done is incredible.

The job they're doing, the job that ISIS is doing, what they're doing, without the protection and the ability to have a wall now -- and by the way, we're building a lot of wall right now, you know that. We're building the wall and it's going up fast, big, strong, looks good, not the horrible thing that they were building before I got here. We're building the wall now. We're going to have a lot of wall built pretty soon. But if you don't have that, you can't have border security.

BARTIROMO: What do you want to go up against in 2020?

TRUMP: So you have people saying a lot of weird things, you know, I hear not only the Green New Deal but so many others, so many things.

BARTIROMO: Medicare of All, tax on wealth, 70 percent tax rates.

TRUMP: You have -- you have Beto -- so you have Beto and Beto comes out and he says, let's take down the wall. If you ever took down the wall, this country would be overrun, OK? And we put up a lot of wall like in San Diego, so interesting, you have California. So, in San Diego they're begging me to do the wall. I end up doing the wall and then I see Governor of California criticizes me for the wall.

They're begging me do it. Because if you don't have it and they know this better. It's all a political deal, it's all politics. But --

BARTIROMO: You want to run against Beto?

TRUMP: You know, my attitude is -- I wouldn't mind. I mean, I'd love to have Biden, I'd love to have Bernie, I'd love to have Beto. I mean, Beto seems to be the one the press has chosen. The press seems to have chosen Beto.

BARTIROMO: Is this socialism versus capitalism?

TRUMP: And when I watched Beto, I say, we could dream about that but whatever it is, no, I think it's competence, I think if somebody -- look, when I first ran, I was never a politicians. I ran -- I ran in a certain platform. I've done far more than I said I was going to do. When you look at the tax cuts, when you look at the regulation cuts, more than any other President. When you look at all -- it's the biggest tax cut. You look at --

(CROSSTALK)

TRUMP: You look at even a thing like right to try, what people can now use if they're terminally ill and they can use medicines that we've developed but that aren't out by signing a simple document. They used to travel to Asia, to Europe, all over the world to try and get a cure. You look at so many things that I've done for the veterans, choice, accountability, they never thought you'd have accountability.

You couldn't fire anybody if they treated our vets badly. Now you have accountability. Veterans choice where if they have to wait two weeks online or they have to two days, they can go out now, Maria, and see a private doctor and we pay for that doctor.

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, let me end on the Golan Heights because you tweeted about this day today in Israel, you said it is time for the U.S. to recognize Israel's s sovereignty and the Golan Heights. Why now? Why did you send that out?

TRUMP: I've been thinking about doing it for a long time. It's been a very hard decision for every President. No President has done it. They've all -- this is very much Jerusalem moving the embassy to Jerusalem. I did that and I fully understand why every -- Clinton and Bush and Obama, everybody campaigned on Jerusalem and the embassy going to Jerusalem. I even got the embassy built by the way very inexpensively.

But they campaigned on it, they never did it and I understand why, because when I got elected, I also campaigned on it. When I got elected, I was inundated with calls from all over the world. The leaders, mostly the leaders saying, please don't do it, don't do it. I did it and it's been done and it's fine. Golan Heights is the same thing for years of other Presidents have campaigned they said they'd do it. This is sovereignty, this is security, this is about regional security.

BARTIROMO: It's not about Netanyahu's reelection.

TRUMP: No. I don't -- I wouldn't even know about that. I wouldn't even know about that. I have no idea. He is doing OK. I don't know if he's doing great right but I hear he is doing OK. But I would imagine the other side whoever is against him is also in favor of what I just did. Every President has said, do that. I'm the one that gets it done.

BARTIROMO: Mr. President, thanks so much.

TRUMP: Thank you. Thank you very much.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile this morning, the Syrian government declared that it will recover the Golan Heights territory. The government reportedly published a statement on the Syrian news agency Web site calling the President's statement "irresponsible" and that showed contempt for international law. My thanks to President Trump. Coming up. The IPO boom. Uber and Pinterest, two of the biggest names on the flat line to go public this year.

Both reportedly making a choice and where they will list their shares. We've got the very latest there. Then big moves for Apple. The technology giant blowing past Microsoft becoming the world's most valuable public company. It's preparing to unveil a new plan for its television service. All the details after this break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tiffany out this morning with mixed earnings. Gerri Willis is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange looking at markets. Gerri, good morning to you.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey. Good morning to you. Yes. Tiffany out with numbers. We look at -- we're looking at a mixed result here. Misses estimates, 1.32 billion on revenues against expectations of 1.33 billion. You see stock down here. EPS, a better story, $1.67 actual versus 1.61. That is tiffany. We also have Nike here, those results I'm waiting on right now. In the premarket it's down almost five percent.

I don't have those numbers at this time. I apologize. I'm going to move on to the IPOs and we can get the Nike numbers up in a second. Uber coming to the NYSE. Big story here after Levi's highly successful IPO yesterday. We have Uber coming to the NYSE. That will be the biggest public offering of the year, possibly the top five in all time. Officially filing in April. That's the expectation and they would be valued $120 billion.

You know, rival Lyft is going to the NASDAQ. And NYSE here been able to score a lot of big tech names, Alibaba, Twitter and now Uber. Pinterest also coming to the NYSE in April. That filing could be out today. They have sped up their offering to take advantage of this Gogo IPO market. They were last valued privately at $12 billion. And Apple has plans for its T.V. service. We're expecting details of that Monday.

Don't expect Netflix, that's not what's happening here. They will sell other company's video subscription and take a cut of their transactions. We're expecting them to bundle services like HBO, Showtime and Starz. That's the expectations for Apple apologize about those Nike earnings. Do we have them? Apple is up premarket as we see a little bit. That's going to be an exciting statement on Monday. Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Gerri. Thank you so much. Nike reported net income of $1.1 billion, that was 68 cents a share. It was compared to a loss of 921 million a year earlier. The issue here was North American sales growth which actually came in weaker than expected. They said things are going well in China but there's also question in terms of China growth given the slowdown there.

So the stock is down 4-2/3 percent largely on the North American sales growth even though the earnings were actually better than expected at 68 cents a share, $1.1 billion. Jon Hilsenrath, what are you watching today?

HILSENRATH: So -- I mean, there's two things from what you just talked about. One was the consumer stocks look like they're a little on the soft side with these two reports, Tiffany and Nike. So we have to look carefully at the consumer right now. They took a hit to their wealth in the fourth quarter, the jobs numbers the last time we saw them for February were close to flat. Now we have to see if consumer spending holds up.

The other thing I'd say though is these IPOs are potentially good news. You know, the IPO market has been so soft for so long and, you know, that's kind of been a sign that the economy isn't really kind of generating a lot of new companies, a lot of innovation. If we see the IPO market opening up and as an outlet for companies to go public, raise capital, it's a good sign for economic growth.

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's a good point but with all those new supply and stock you wonder how the market absorbs it. So, I wonder, yes, it's a good news that we got such a boom in IPOs but whether or not, investors are going to be able to absorb that and whether or not it means the broader market trades down is something to watch as well. Matt, you wanted to make a comment?

SCHLAPP: Yes. Real quickly on your interview with President Trump which I thought was great. The key thing that I don't think it's covered enough by reporters is that 24 hours before Mr. Mueller is picked to be the special counsel, the President tells him he will not pick him again to run the FBI. So, the President essentially gilt Bob Mueller and then he has to read in the paper that Bob Mueller has this job of being the Special Counsel looking after the President.

The conflict there is just so odious that that in and of itself, you can see why the President sits in this craw that just could ever happen.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And not only that but the Special Counsel investigation was based on the FBI investigation into President Trump, then-candidate Trump which was based on real flimsy evidence.

(CROSSTALK)

SCHLAPP: You couldn't make this up if it was a story of fiction.

BARTIROMO: It's an extraordinary story, it's like a movie what they did. Coming up. General Motors' mega investment. The automaker ready to pour hundreds of millions of dollars into a Midwest plant. What it means for the company. Back in a minute. Then, forever friends, marking National Puppy Day. We have the breed just named America's favorite. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. More fallout from Boeing following the deadly crash of two of its 737 Max jets. Cheryl Casone with details there. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. Indonesia's flagship carrier Garuda Indonesia is seeking to cancel an order for 49 of Boeing 747 Max planes because customers don't think the aircraft is safe. This is the first set request following crashes in Indonesia and Ethiopia. The jets were grounded worldwide this month after an Ethiopian Airline crashed that killed all 157 people onboard. Taking a look at shares of Boeing, fractionally lower in the premarket right now.

Well drugmakers, Biogen and Eisai into their recent experimental Alzheimer's drug trial. That (INAUDIBLE) yesterday. The Biogen stock fell 29 percent. Shares of Eisai dropped 35 percent. Meanwhile, analyst are predicting that Biogen's next move might be an acquisition of a -- investment plan this morning and Michigan. G.M. plans to invest $300 million in its Oriion Assembly plant to build a new electric vehicle for Chevy.

The plant is already producing an electric car. The Chevy bolt and a self-driving vehicle for G.M. Cruise unit. Now this becomes after G.M. said it's going to close its plant in Ohio, that, of course, angered President Trump. We're going to learn more about the plan from G.M. CEO Mara Barra on "VARNEY & COMPANY" 10 a.m. Eastern Time today.

OK. There's this. OK. There is this. Lots of Labrador love out there. The breed once again has landed on top in America for the 28th year in a row. The near three-decade run is kind of impressive and a German Shepherd, Golden Retriever, French bulldogs and then bulldogs round out the top five. An in honor of National Puppy Day, Maria. Congratulations on your new edition. Baby Bella, I'm sure she can't wait to see it. She probably really misses you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. I was so happy to have Bella Dusty at home. I missed her. I haven't been home in a week.

CASONE: I know.

BARTIROMO: So we'll celebrate National Puppy Day when I get home. Dagen, are you going to be celebrating with Charlie this weekend?

MCDOWELL: Yes. We celebrate every day and people even yesterday because I talked to him like he is a person out in public and people think that I've completely lost my mind. But I would say this, rescue is our favorite breed, although I do love a lab. There is a lab who is a working dog in the building. Her name is Persia. And Persia when I see her, she looks at me and flips over on her back and sticks all four legs in the air because she wants belly-rub.

She's supposed to be on the job and she's not but I will give her -- I always come up with some belly scratches for her. So --

BARTIROMO: Nothing comes between belly rubs.

MCDOWELL: No. belly rubs.

BARTIROMO: And puppies.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Belly rubs. You know what I'm talking about.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Happy National Puppy Day, Dagen. All right. We'll take a break. When we come back. Defending the Green New Deal. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez says her proposal is being misinterpreted.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SETH MEYERS, NBC HOST: You would outlaw cows --

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D), NEW YORK: Oh, yes.

MEYERS: Cows farting, that would be out. Children, hamburgers, ice cream.

OCASIO-CORTEZ: It's always good to see how these narratives are manipulated.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will discuss it and then more of my exclusive interview with President Trump. Don't miss it. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo live this morning in Washington. It is Friday, March 22nd, your top stories right now 8:31 a.m. on the east coast. President Trump slamming the impending Mueller report in my exclusive interview.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: It's all a big hoax, it's a witch hunt and it's a hoax. We have been treated very, very unfairly all because Jeff Sessions didn't have a clue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: We will get reaction from former House Oversight Committee Chairman Jason Chaffetz, coming up this morning. We're taking a look at weakness at the opening of trading, Futures indicating a decline of almost 200 points. This is taking a cue from Europe because we had Purchasing Managers' Index surveys out in France, in Germany. A number of the European PMIs were weaker than expecting, showing that manufacturing within the Eurozone is weakening. We know that it's expected to grow one percent, the Eurozone is in 2019. So, that is weighing on European markets, and the U.S. is following suite.

European down across the board, FT-100 is down 100, 1-1/3 percent; CAC Quarante down 73, also 1-1/3 percent; and the DAX Index in Germany down 95 points. Germany has had a tough -- rough go at it this week, after the Bayer sell-off as well. It is down, again, almost one percent on the DAX Index. In Asia overnight, markets were fractionally moving, but they were higher across the board.

Our top story this half an hour, the Green New Deal, New York Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez speaking out on the Green New Deal last night on "Late Night."

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OCASIO-CORTEZ: They're trying to say that the Green New Deal is about what we have to give up, what we have to cut back on, when in fact, the Green New Deal itself is a resolution to be more expansive. It is to be able to generate more and to make sure that we're investing in working class -- in working-class Americans.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I asked President Trump about the Green New Deal in my exclusive sit-down yesterday. Here's what he had to say about it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The Democrats actually are becoming a far-left party. You look at this Green New Deal, it's the most preposterous thing. Now, I don't want to knock it too much right now, because I really hope they keep going forward with it, you know, frankly, because I think it's going to be very easy to beat.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And Douglas Holtz-Eakin's group says it's going to cost $94 trillion. Joining is right now is former Utah Congressman, former House Oversight Committee Chairman, and Fox News Contributor, Jason Chaffetz. Jason, it's great to see you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us this morning. First, your thoughts on the Green New Deal, and whether or not this has legs. Every time Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez talks about it, she basically refers to it as broad strokes. You know, don't worry about the fact that it doesn't make sense, don't worry about the fact that we're obviously not going to get rid of fossil fuels in the next 10 years. That makes no sense. It's just an idea. What do you think?

CHAFFETZ: Well, it's an actual piece of legislation that has been embraced by most of the Democratic 2020 candidates on the Democratic side of the party, so there's a lot to about worried about there. The economics make no sense, the absurdity on its face is ridiculous. But let's be careful as Republicans as from -- as a Republican point of view to summarily dismiss it when I think it'd be a mistake. Because she is communicating with a younger generation who maybe hasn't looked at the economics of it, and they think, well, why can't we do these things? If you believe that the world is going to end because of plastic straws in the next 10 years, you're looking at this and thinking this is a viable piece of legislation and you should do it.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CHAFFETZ: But Republicans have also got to communicate why they believe -- or what they can do to help the planet, and they can't just say, oh, it's ridiculous or they're going to lose a huge section of the younger -- the younger population.

BARTIROMO: Yes, is that why the Democrats want the voting age to start at 16 years old, Matt Schlapp?

SCHLAPP: Yes, I mean, there is this -- this is the work I do at CPAC. You know, half of the people that come to our events are high school kids and college kids. So, we haven't lost that generation, but Jason is right, we have to reach out and talk to them. The Democrats think that they own certain groups of Americans, and I think we're still -- people have my point of view, we are still being listened to, but we've got to deconstruct why the Green New Deal will harm them.

HILSENRATH: How do you talk to them about the environment if --

SCHLAPP: Easily. Easily.

HILSENRATH: The Green New Deal is a no-go for me. How do you --

SCHLAPP: No, it's very easy. Carbon is not pollution. This is the problem. We could spend money combating pollution, having cleaner air, or cleaner water, or we could take that same money where we -- instead of combating pollution, we can do this all hoax, this facade over CO2, which will do nothing but raise people's energy prices. It's nothing but a war on fossil fuels. It's a diversion from cleaning up our environment.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let me move on to the Mueller report, Jason, because President Trump wade in during my interview, and former FBI Director Jim Comey wrote an op-ed in The New York Times titled this, "What I Want From the Mueller Report." In this op-ed, Comey writes in part, "Even though I believe Mr. Trump is morally unfit to be President of the United States, I'm not rooting for Mr. Mueller to demonstrate that he is a criminal. I'm also not rooting for Mr. Mueller to clear the President. I'm not rooting for anything at all, except that the special counsel be permitted to finish his work."

Now, in my exclusive interview yesterday, I had the chance to ask the President about this ongoing probe into Russia collusion, and this narrative nonsense of the last two years. Here's what he said.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And now, we're going to get the Mueller report. What are you expecting?

TRUMP: Well, it's always interesting to me because a deputy that didn't get any votes appoints a man that didn't get any votes. He's going to write a report on me. I had one of the greatest election victories in history. Would you say that's true?

BARTIROMO: Yes, absolutely.

TRUMP: They came from the valleys, they came from the rivers, they came from the cities, they came from all over, they voted in one of the greatest elections in the history of our country. And now, I have a man that because we have an attorney general who -- nobody can even believe that he didn't tell me, but he recused himself. So, I have a man who is a deputy who I don't know, who I didn't know at all, and he appoints a man who had just left my office. I didn't give him the job at the FBI. For two years, we've gone through this nonsense. With no -- because there's no collusion with Russia. You know that better than anybody. And there's no obstruction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Jason, I find it so ironic that here is Jim Comey writing this op-ed, meanwhile, he was the Director of the FBI at the time. He knew he had flimsy evidence to actually wiretap an American citizen, just so that they could spy on a political enemy's campaign. He knew that Hillary Clinton was actually a part of the dossier's history and paid for it, and then he writes this whole op-ed as if he's neutral.

CHAFFETZ: Well, yes, you read the op-ed and it's rich with irony, because you're exactly right, the -- and the President is right about Director Comey here, too. You know, Comey tries to go to great lengths to say that the President has been tearing apart the rule of law. To the contrary, the President has let this process play out with arm's length. He has professed his innocence as an innocent person would do time and time and time again. He waived the executive privilege, he opened up to interviews, he provided all the documents. What else do you want a President to do?

BARTIROMO: Right.

CHAFFETZ: And so, I think the -- I think the President is on the right side of this. What James Comey did to Hillary Clinton, I think the way he did it was absolutely wrong, he started exonerating her before they had even interviewed her. I mean, the list is long, and if you look at the senior most leadership at the FBI, it is disastrous. The top echelon there has done a great disservice to this country, and torn down the belief in the FBI that was there before. My grandfather was a career FBI agent. But I got to tell you, the more we learn about Comey, we -- the more we learn that the way he administered that department was fundamentally wrong.

BARTIROMO: Well, they had those two investigations going side-by-side, the Hillary Clinton e-mail investigation and the Trump collusion investigation. And now, we know from the Lisa Page testimony that the (INAUDIBLE) released, they were told at the FBI, lay off Hillary from the DOJ, Obama's DOJ.

CHAFFETZ: And you combine that with Mr. Baker's testimony, the general counsel there, and then you start to see a pattern that what Comey testified in front of Congress, was not true. That there was never a chance for lady justice to actually administer justice. It was just absolutely wrong.

BARTIROMO: Good op-ed in the Journal about this today by Kim Strassel, Matt.

SCHLAPP: Yes, absolutely. I think the key thing here is that for those of us who were saying that Hillary Clinton was guilty of breaking the law, and that Obama's Department of Justice is actually the guilty party in getting involved in the investigations in calling off the FBI, and the prosecutors at DOJ. Who's going to apologize for all these two years of people saying that that was made up and that was, you know, that was wrong?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

SCHLAPP: We wasted two years of our political discourse talking about a fiction, and we allowed all the wrongdoing to occur, and it's travesty.

BARTIROMO: So, the question is, William Barr, Jason, is he going to seek the truth, the A.G.?

CHAFFETZ: Yes, I think he has the degree of creditability on both sides of the aisle. He is -- he's got a great background on this. And ironically, if you look at what happened -- because James Comey basically set this up so the special prosecutor would be there, the irony of all of this is I don't think there will be any charges or any evidence of any collusion. We'll see. But that's what you would think at this point. And without any of that, guess what, the President comes out of this stronger than ever, because he will have the support of that document behind him. And all of these people who've been flailing about the President going down, the President will be stronger politically than ever.

BARTIROMO: Well, we should get the Mueller report, if not this weekend, next week, it is coming. We have a lot of evidence to believe that the report should be out within the next few days. Jason -- yes, go ahead, real quick.

HILSENRATH: Is that a reason to make it public? We were having this discussion earlier. Should all of this stuff be out there? So, Jason, you say that this is -- you know, this will exonerate the President. Do you think the whole thing should be out there from the get-go?

CHAFFETZ: Your gut says yes. There are certain material under the law, a grand jury testimony among the things that cannot be released. So, don't get caught up in that, oh, Democrats will flail about -- hey, we want all of it released. But under the law, not all of it can be released.

BARTIROMO: Yes, understood. Jason, good to see you this morning.

CHAFFETZ: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Jason Chaffetz in Utah. Coming up, more of my exclusive sit-down with the President. Stuart Varney weighs in on that. And then, our favorite moments from the week right here. MORNINGS WITH MARIA, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. President Trump and I covered a lot of ground yesterday during my one-on-one exclusive with him. Joining me now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in. Good morning, Stu.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: I don't want to weigh in. I want to ask you a question.

BARTIROMO: Oh, OK.

VARNEY: I wonder if that's legit or not, but I'm going to ask you anyway.

BARTIROMO: Sure.

VARNEY: OK. Of all the points that you made with the President, in that great interview, what's the single most important point that you should -- that you want to put before our viewers at 9:00? What is it?

BARTIROMO: Well, I think you want to look at economic growth and whether or not he can keep this going. I mean, he said that the Federal Reserve in raising interest rates actually hampered growth. Now, we did see a 3.1 percent economic growth year-over-year, fourth quarter to fourth quarter, '17 tor '18. But he said that it could have been four percent, if the Fed did not raise rates. Obviously, the news around Mueller was important, as the -- as the Mueller report is going to drop soon.

His reaction to -- his talking about John McCain and why he is so upset with the late senator, because McCain gave the dossier, which of course, was salacious and unverified to the FBI. That, I thought, was also worth a mention in terms of what's behind this upset. Obviously, you know, a lot of people on both sides of the aisle are upset with him, that he keeps talking about him. And I think the news that he broke yesterday Golan Heights ahead of the election in Israel, also worthwhile.

But when it comes to the economic stuff, the China news is important, we've got a meeting next week. Lighthizer and Steven Mnuchin going to China. He said a deal could get done. He's expecting a deal to get done. I wonder if, in fact, the Chinese are pushing back on I.P. theft and whether or not, they're ever really going to be able to change that behavior, because I think it's a culture. But I also think the fact that the President said we can come up with some enforcement mechanisms to keep them in line is worthwhile as well.

VARNEY: That's a lot of stuff. Why don't you come over and start at 9:00 and tell everybody all over again, why don't you?

BARTIROMO: Well, that's just my two cents, Stu, but, you know?

VARNEY: About two dollars' worth, actually.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: Maria, that was great. Thank you very much indeed.

BARTIROMO: I know you have a big interview, coming up, Jeff Flock is going to interview Mary Barra. And of course, the President has been pressuring G.M. to either sell that plant or reopen it in Ohio. So, we'll see what Mary Barra has to say about that on your show.

VARNEY: I -- wait, I want to see what she's going to say about this pressure from the President about Lordstown. She'll have an answer, I'm sure. OK.

BARTIROMO: All right, Stu, we'll see you in 10 minutes. Thanks so much.

VARNEY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA 9:00 a.m. Eastern. Join Stuart, coming up. But first, our favorite moments from this past week on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We've been on the road. Don't miss it. Back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. It's been a big week here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA. We've been on the road. Take a look at some of the top moments from the program.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARTIROMO: Under your administration's policy, we've seen growth in the economy, in jobs, the stock market, but now, the rest of the world is slowing. How are you going to keep this elevated growth going?

TRUMP: And you look at what's going on with respect to China. Our deal is coming along very well. We'll see what happens. But we're taking in billions and billions of dollars for the first time ever against China in the form of tariffs. I'm very happy with that, but I think the deal will probably happen. I think they need it very badly. The world going in a little bit the wrong direction, not horribly. I think a lot of people are waiting for the deal with China. I think that's going to have a very big impact, maybe bigger than people know. As to whether or not it makes it, I think it will. I had Facebook, Google, Twitter, everybody against me. I have the medias, almost totally against me, and yet I won.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the vitriol happening today in Washington?

JOHN BOEHNER, FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: So, it was crazy enough when I was there. It's just gotten exponentially more crazy since I left. Both parties are being held hostage by the extreme wings in their party. And any idea that there should be -- there will be any cooperation is -- it's just not going to happen. And so, it's messy, but listen, it's democracy.

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSEL TO PRESIDENT TRUMP: I'm not being asked to chose between my marriage and my job, Donald Trump has never made -- the President has never made me feel that way, Maria. I know George was quoted recently as saying, I don't -- I wish she didn't work there.

BARTIROMO: So, does he want you to step down? George -- does George say --

CONWAY: Certainly. Certainly.

KEVIN HASEETT, CHAIRMAN, COUNCIL OF ECONOMIC ADVISERS: Capex number is really the source of all the good news, because we're getting a capital expenditure boom, up about nine percent since the tax cuts passed. And that nine percent capital spending boom is creating jobs. And this year, it's going to create output and also continue. And we can see that in the orders data.

GEN. JACK KEANE (RET.), FOX NEWS SENIOR STRATEGIC ANALYST: It's absolutely staggering how prolific the Chinese are, who are the number one penetrators of our cyberspace.

SUSAN DEVORE, PRESIDENT & CEO, PREMIER: Innovation needs to continue in the development of new drugs, but we have to get the control over the pricing of drugs.

KATIE COURIC, AWARD-WINNING JOURNALIST: We definitely need people to be more engaged, and to get involved in science, because that really is the solution, it's nonpartisan, it really -- it transcends politics, and it's the key to solving incurable diseases, climate change, and environment issues.

KEVIN JOHNSON, CEO, STARBUCKS: I think the competition, globally, around the addressable market of coffee has been -- has been increasing over the last three to five years. You know, some of it is start-up companies or third wave independents, but you've seen, you know, many large companies making acquisitions, and doing consolidation around the industry of coffee. You know, for Starbucks, we've stayed focused on the formula who's worked for us for the last 48 years.

BARTIROMO: Survey shows that three in five millennials say that life is more stressful for them right now than ever before.

JOY VILLA, SINGER-SONGWRITER: I mean, losing your phone charger, having a cracked phone screen, not getting enough likes on your social media, these are the things that millennials have problems with now.

CASONE: Sesame Street releasing Muppet stamps to celebrate the show's 50th anniversary. Meanwhile, Sesame Street has caused a heated debate on Twitter. Here's what they tweeted, they asked, "Which of the Muppets would you take on a deserted island with you?" Well, how about you? What do you think?

BARTIROMO: I'm going to go with you, Cookie Monster.

CASONE: Cookie -- OK, Cookie Monster. There you go.

BARTIROMO: Dagen, what about you?

MCDOWELL: Since I am Oscar the Grouch, you do not want to be stuck on a deserted island with me.

(LAUGHTER)

(END VIDEOTAPE)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: All right, welcome back with our all-star panel. Final thoughts, Matt Schlapp?

SCHLAPP: Yet another Trump accomplishment, that executive order on free speech on college campuses. Way to go.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's true. You're right.

HILSENRATH: You covered a lot of ground with the President on trade. That's the big issue for the markets. We're coming down to the wire. We have to see if he gets something done with China.

BARTIROMO: Are they going to be able to do an enforcement enough to actually keep China to its promises to not steal I.P.?

HILSENRATH: That's one of many issues and that's why one of the things he said is important, that they want to keep some of these tariffs in place until they see some of this -- some of these agreements coming to fruition.

BARTIROMO: Dagen?

MCDOWELL: He also said to you which made my ears burn, no to zero tariffs with Europe on automobiles. And he actually praised the 25 percent import tariffs on light trucks, called the Chicken Tax, which your viewers know because we've talked about it literally for two years on this program.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That was important, you're right, the zero taxes. He doesn't want to go there.

MCDOWELL: Right.

BARTIROMO: That will do it for today. Thanks, everybody. Great panel, great program. Have a great weekend. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

END

Aired: 3-4p ET2019-04-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:40:48ZLexisNexisDonald Trump Says The U.S. Has The World's Best Economy; NASDAQ Has Been Flooding With All-Time Highs Throughout The Week; There Are Calls For New Sanctions On Saudi Arabia Tonight; Maria Butina Gets 18 Months in U.S. Prison; Uber Aims to Price Shares at $44 to $50 in IPO; PepsiCo Sues Indian Farmers Over Exclusive Potatoes. Aired: 3-4p ETLanhamFULL TEXT

ZAIN ASHER, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR: We've got a very exciting end to the trading day here on a Friday on Wall Street, we're pretty much flat, even hovering up and down all day. We did get better than expected best quarter GDP, but Intel and Exxon Mobil earnings weighing on the market. We are an hour away from the end of trading.

She joins us live now from London. It -- you know, Hannah, it does actually seem rather aggressive to have this multi-national -- multi-billion dollar company suing four small farmers. I mean, these farmers can't really be that much of a threat, can they?

HANNAH LOWNSBROUGH, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR, SUMOFUS: We don't think so. I think some of us members feel that, you know, this is a really good example of a very large corporation taking on very small -- a very small pro -- you know, in many cases family-run businesses and going after them for amounts of money that are kind of spare change to a company like PepsiCo, but can be absolutely ruin for you know, for a small farmer.

ASHER: How are the farmers actually supposed to know that a company like Pepsi has exclusive rights to a certain type of potato?

LOWNSBROUGH: Well, I mean, I think this is exactly the question that some of us members, you know, would ask really. And it sort of highlights the way in which it makes -- it's a bit of a nonsense really when these huge corporations seem to own things like seeds or water supply. These sorts of things which, you know, to most people's way of thinking really belong to all of us.

So, you know, we're not surprised that the farmers, you know, didn't really believe themselves to be doing anything wrong, and that this lawsuit has come as a huge shock and is completely overwhelming.

ASHER: The lawsuit for -- was for over a $100,000 for each of the farmers. I mean, when you have a massive -- I mean, I can't even imagine what it's like to be a small time farmer in a place like India and having Pepsi suing you. I mean, how do farmers protect themselves?

LOWNSBROUGH: Well, I think it's difficult. I think we're seeing civil society in India has really come forward to stand with these farmers and challenge the behavior of PepsiCo in this case. But also you know, similar corporations. You mentioned Amazon in the introduction, you know, who have also been accused of doing things which are really damaging many Indian domestic operations.

[15:45:00] And I think there's some evidence that the Indian government is taking steps to regulate, but these are -- these are tough questions to answer because it is critically important that, you know, we don't end up in a situation where a handful of companies are you know, owning the seeds that we rely on to produce our food supply or, you know, are responsible for almost all the business that gets done online.

ASHER: So Pepsi's argument is that they filed this lawsuit to protect the interest of thousands of farmers who are part of its potato farming program. Is that a fair argument do you think?

LOWNSBROUGH: I don't think so really. I mean, I think you know, you asked a good question at the beginning which is, you know, how are they supposed to know really that these seeds are sort of, you know, they belong to somebody else. But I also think that, you know, arguably, PepsiCo is really setting up a relationship of dependency between some of these farmers with whom it has its cultivation -- farmers with whom it has its cultivation program.

We're seeing examples in some cases for instance of seeds being developed that can -- will only grow and will only thrive if they're also raised using fertilizers or what have you, that are also produced by some of these parent companies. So you are seeing sort of small farmers really ending up sort of in-hawked to some of these very big businesses.

And it's hard to see that as kind of, you know, creating the conditions in which everybody can make a success of -- make a success of a small business.

ASHER: All right, Hannah, thank you so much for being with us, appreciate that.

LOWNSBROUGH: Thank you.

ASHER: OK, so from the farms of India, we are taking you to the lush landscape, that is Hawaii. If you're going to do the hula dance, you better get your hips in gear. Richard Quest is going to be showing us all how it's done, we'll be talking tourism in two shakes, that's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

[15:50:00] ASHER: That music should be a clue to where we're heading next. I'm filling in for Richard Quest this Friday night, but he actually doesn't have a day off, he's got an extremely difficult awful assignment filming one of the most beautiful remote islands in the entire world. Richard Quest joins us live now from Waikiki Beach in Hawaii.

Richard, I was there six months ago actually in Kuhio, and it's beautiful, looks as though, Richard -- it looks as though sadly, Richard can't hear me. It looks as though we'll have to come back to him. All right, now, you don't need Hawaii's natural beauty to enjoy a holiday.

For the CEOs of Radisson hotels, beautiful design might be the key to beating the opposition in a crowded hotel market. Richard went to meet Federico Gonzalez for a tour of the world's first ever design hotel. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

RICHARD QUEST, CNN (voice-over): The Royal Radisson hotel in Copenhagen. The world's first design hotel, it dominated the skyline for more than five decades. And it's here that I meet Radisson's chief executive, Federico Gonzales.

FEDERICO GONZALEZ, PRESIDENT & CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, RADISSON HOSPITALITY: Well, I think it helps, but at the same time it's really exciting with their latest and you really can't sign --

QUEST: Federico manages Radisson's seven brands, and more than 1,400 hotels worldwide.

(on camera): Is it intimidating competing for example against Marriott with its million rooms over more than 30 brands?

GONZALEZ: No, not at all, it's exciting. When I look to Radisson Hotel Group, and what we are doing in our building is much stronger and it will last much longer.

QUEST (voice-over): For Radisson, it's been a bumpy ride. Three years and three different owners.

(on camera): I'm often left wondering what is Radisson?

GONZALEZ: It's towards those consumers who do not want or cannot pay the price of the high, but they want a more memorable experience and they want something more exceptional. So we call it affordable luxury.

QUEST (voice-over): And so to this design elite hotel, the Royal Copenhagen, the vision of the architect Arnie Jacobson.

GONZALEZ: Welcome in.

QUEST: Nice --

GONZALEZ: This was the inner room where he stays because he wanted to really know and understand what was lightening, what was the views, how the views would change.

QUEST: This hotel is where savings meets functionality, according to Gonzales.

(on camera): These lights.

GONZALEZ: Yes, if we would build this today, it's much more cost effective than putting 20 different lights across.

QUEST (voice-over): But I'm going to interview a hotel CEO, and of course, we have to test the most important part of the place.

GONZALEZ: You are now behind a bit, right?

QUEST (on camera): Right --

GONZALEZ: And then you can feel not only the bed, the mattress, also the tissue. Now, what is more important is, what are the figures you have? And if in your highest lead, you can choose where to sleep, different textures, different size, and then now you can look to your temptations. This is really temptations.

QUEST: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.

GONZALEZ: Oh, you should have another one.

QUES: And as for customer service, no skimping there.

GONZALEZ: It is a culture. This is a company where every employee or associate is absolutely obsessed with servicing them, and they are worth every moment matters.

QUEST (voice-over): An inspiring strategy that will ensure this proud hotel group will remain my host.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

ASHER: All right, let's try this again, Richard Quest is joining us live now from Waikiki Beach, I believe he can hear me. So Richard, as beautiful, as stunning as it looks there behind you, I was surprised to hear that tourists spending on Hawaii is actually falling. Why is that?

QUEST: And it's interesting, that's one of the conundrums, Zain, that they don't quite understand. In that report you heard how hoteliers are having to find new ways, different things that tourists want. And that's certainly the same case. Let's take Waikiki Beach in Hawaii where I am for World of Wonder.

Look, it's packed. There's no shortage of people who are coming here, actually visitor numbers are up by some 2 percent to 4 percent. But the spending, and that's the important part in many ways, the spend is down. And this is something that many resorts are finding happening.

And Zain, what's really worrying about this is spend is the holy grail, with a resort like Hawaii and Honolulu, you want more tourists, but you want the right sort of tourists, you want them to stay longer and you want them to spend more. So Zain, that's one of the interesting things. It is paradise, but it's paradise with clouds on the horizon.

[15:55:00] ASHER: And just talk to us a bit more about hula dancing. I understand that you got to try some yourself, Richard.

QUEST: Yes, because we're here for World of Wonder. And one of the important things about is, is what's the DNA of this place? The 50th state of the union, we're familiar with Hawaii 5-0. I was determined to get that in. We're familiar with all of that.

But what about hula? So I got a chance to try it out and realize it's not the tacky coconut bras and grass skirts that you often see. My hula wasn't very good, but it gives me an understanding of the spiritual DNA of Hawaii. And this afternoon, I get to try surfing, because again, as the Duke showed some years ago, surfing is part of the spiritual heritage of these islands.

ASHER: Richard, you've got skills, I just watched that video, you are great at hula dancing, I'm inspired. Richard Quest live for us there, thank you so much. All right, so just a few minutes to go for the end of trading week on Wall Street. After the break, we've got the final numbers and the closing bell. That's next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

ASHER: All right, so let's take a look at the numbers in the last few minutes of trade on Wall Street. As you can see behind me, the Dow is actually basically flat, up about 57 points or so. And we've hovered up and down throughout the session, despite some pretty good, I should say stellar numbers in terms of first quarter GDP.

The Dow has been dragged down by Intel earnings that aren't necessarily that great, and also ExxonMobil earnings as well. And my producer, Tom, simply cannot contain his excitement because we're told that the Wu-Tang Clan is going to be ringing the closing bell today at some part to celebrate a documentary on "Showtime" that is about them of "Mics and Men".

And as I mentioned, it was all about stronger-than-expected first quarter growth in terms of GDP in the United States, combined though with surprisingly weak inflation. All of that should make for a fascinating debate when it comes to the Fed decision about the direction of rates.

They're not going to raise interest rates this year, but who knows? Policy makers do end up meeting next week. And that is the closing bell on Wall Street. As I mentioned, the Wu-Tang Clan as you can see up there is actually ringing the closing bell this Friday, and that is it my friends for QUEST MEANS BUSINESS, I am Zain Asher, thank you so much for joining us, the news continues right here on CNN.

(APPLAUSE)

(BELL RINGING)

END
